nodes.excerpt: Magento 2 is a comprehensive e-commerce platform that provides online store owners with an array of tools and features to manage their online business with ease. This platform simplifies the process of creating and managing an online store, from product management to promotion strategies and more. nodes.content:
Magento 2 is a comprehensive e-commerce platform that provides online store owners with an array of tools and features to manage their online business with ease. This platform simplifies the process of creating and managing an online store, from product management to promotion strategies and more.

In today’s online marketplace, landing pages are critical components of any effective marketing strategy. They are specifically designed to deliver a clear and concise message to your target audience, with the ultimate goal of driving conversions. A well-crafted landing page not only showcases the unique features of your product or service, but also provides visitors with the information they need to make informed purchasing decisions.

In this blog, we will guide you through the process of creating high-converting landing pages in Magento 2. From setting goals and designing effective layouts, to optimizing for search engines and testing performance, our step-by-step instructions and expert tips will help you tailor your landing pages to meet your business needs and achieve optimal results. So, let’s get started and explore how to build landing pages in Magento 2 store.

Needs to Build Landing Pages in Magento 2 store

There are several reasons why it is important to build landing pages in Magento 2:

Increased Conversions: 

The purpose of landing pages is to concentrate on a particular objective, such as enhancing sales or generating leads. By constructing targeted and optimized landing pages, you can boost conversions and accomplish the desired result.

Better User Experience: 

The purpose of landing pages is to concentrate on a particular objective, such as enhancing sales or generating leads. By constructing targeted and optimized landing pages, you can boost conversions and accomplish the desired result.

Improved SEO: 

When your landing pages are optimized for search engines, they can help improve your search engine rankings and drive more traffic to your online store. By carefully selecting relevant keywords, crafting compelling meta descriptions, and strategically using internal links, you can boost the visibility of your landing pages in search results. This, in turn, can lead to more organic traffic and potentially increase your chances of converting visitors into customers.

Increased Engagement: 

Having visually appealing and easy-to-navigate landing pages can significantly improve engagement and encourage visitors to stay on your website for longer periods. By doing so, you can increase your chances of having higher conversion rates and creating a better overall user experience for your visitors.

Improved Marketing Efforts: 

By utilizing landing pages, you can concentrate your marketing efforts and communicate a targeted message to your intended audience. These pages can be utilized to advertise specific products or services or provide comprehensive information about your brand.

Better Data Tracking: 

By leveraging landing pages, it becomes simpler to monitor the effectiveness of your marketing strategies and make informed decisions based on data insights. By utilizing analytical tools, you can track visitor behavior and optimize your landing pages accordingly to boost conversions and achieve your desired outcomes.

Things to keep in mind when building landing pages in Magento 2

Here are some additional important things to keep in mind when building landing pages in Magento 2:

Mobile Responsiveness: 

Ensuring your landing page is mobile-responsive is crucial as more and more online shoppers rely on their mobile devices. By doing so, you can ensure a seamless and positive user experience across all devices, leading to increased engagement and potential conversions.

Navigation: 

Ensuring a user-friendly navigation system on your landing page is crucial. Implementing intuitive features like a menu bar, footer links, or breadcrumb trail can simplify the visitor’s browsing experience and help them find the information they need with ease.

Loading Speed: 

Ensuring that your landing page loads quickly is essential for both user experience and search engine optimization. To achieve this, optimizing images, compressing CSS and JavaScript files, and selecting a fast web hosting provider are necessary steps. By prioritizing page loading speed, you can improve your website’s overall performance and enhance the user experience.

Testing: 

It’s crucial to ensure that your landing page functions correctly after building it. You can conduct tests on various devices and browsers to guarantee its performance. Analytical tools like Google PageSpeed Insights are also useful in identifying any areas that need improvement.

Analytics: 

To keep track of the performance of your landing page, you can utilize analytics tools. By analyzing metrics such as visitor count, dwell time, and user behavior, you can identify areas that require improvement and optimize your page accordingly to increase conversions.

A/B Testing: 

A/B testing is an effective method to enhance your landing page and boost conversions. By creating two versions of your landing page and comparing their performance, you can make informed decisions based on data and constantly enhance the performance of your landing page.

Conversion Optimization: 

By taking into account these additional considerations, you will be on the right path towards creating effective and high-converting landing pages in Magento 2.

Steps to Build Landing Pages in Magento 2

Install a Landing Page Extension

To create a landing page in Magento 2, you need to install a landing page extension. There are several free and paid extensions available so you can install extension from the Magento 2 Marketplace. Choose the extension that best fits your needs and install it in your Magento 2 store.

Create a New Page

Once the extension is installed, log in to the Magento 2 backend and navigate to the Pages section. Here, you will find an option to create a new page. Fill in the required information such as page title, URL key, and content.

Customize the Design

Next, you need to customize the design of your landing page. You can do this using the built-in design editor or by adding custom CSS. You can also add images, videos, and other multimedia elements to make your landing page more engaging.

Add Call-to-Action Buttons

A landing page should have clear call-to-action buttons to encourage visitors to take a specific action. In Magento 2, you can add call-to-action buttons such as “Buy Now,” “Learn More,” or “Sign Up” to your landing page.

Publish the Page

Once you have completed the design and added all necessary elements, it’s time to publish your landing page. Navigate to the Pages section and select the page you want to publish. Click the “Publish” button to make the page live.

Optimize for Search Engines

Finally, it’s important to optimize your landing page for search engines. This involves adding meta titles, descriptions, and keywords to help search engines understand the content of your page. You can also add internal and external links to improve the user experience and search engine rankings.

Conclusion 

In conclusion, building landing pages in Magento 2 store is easy and straightforward. With the right extension, you can create professional and engaging landing pages in no time. Follow the steps outlined in this blog, and you’ll be able to create landing pages that drive traffic and increase conversions,user experience, and overall marketing efforts for your online store.

nodes.title: Magento 2 Change Admin URL: How to Set a Custom Admin URL
nodes.excerpt: Magento 2 is a popular e-commerce platform that stands out for its broad range of customization options. One critical aspect of ensuring the security of any online store is to secure the backend or admin panel from unauthorized access. Magento 2 provides a vital feature that enables users to customize the default admin URL with … Read more
nodes.content:
Magento 2 is a popular e-commerce platform that stands out for its broad range of customization options. One critical aspect of ensuring the security of any online store is to secure the backend or admin panel from unauthorized access. Magento 2 provides a vital feature that enables users to customize the default admin URL with a preferred URL of their choice. This additional security layer makes it significantly harder for hackers to guess and access the admin panel, thereby protecting the website from potential cyber attacks. 

This blog post takes an in-depth look at the process of Magento 2 Change Admin URL: How to Set a Custom Admin URL, highlighting the necessary steps in detail to provide a comprehensive understanding of the procedure. 

After reading this post, you will have the knowledge and confidence to secure your online store’s admin panel with a custom URL, enhancing the overall security of your e-commerce website.

Why Change the Magento 2 Admin URL?

Hackers are aware of the default Magento 2 admin URL, making it easier for them to guess and gain unauthorized access to the backend. However, by changing the default URL to a custom one, you can considerably increase the difficulty for hackers to guess and access the backend. This simple yet effective security measure can significantly enhance the security of your website, providing an added layer of protection against potential cyber attacks.

Benefits of Changing Magento 2 Admin URL

Changing the default admin URL offers several benefits that can enhance the security and overall user experience of your website. 

Firstly, it significantly increases the security of your website by making it harder for hackers to guess and access the backend, thereby reducing the risk of cyber attacks.

Secondly, opting for a custom URL allows you to select a relevant and memorable URL that aligns with your website and brand, making it easier for users to remember and access your admin panel.

Lastly, customizing your backend URLs enables you to organize your backend sections in a way that makes sense for your business, facilitating easier and more efficient access to relevant sections of the backend. By implementing these simple but effective measures, you can improve the overall functionality, security, and organization of your website.

Tips for Choosing a Custom URL

Make it memorable: Opt for a memorable URL that relates to your business.

Avoid common terms: Refrain from using common terms like “admin,” “login,” and “backend” since they are popular and simple to guess.

Use a mix of letters and numbers: Employ a combination of letters and numbers to create a more complex URL that is harder to guess.

Keep it short: Shorten the URL to make it easier to remember and less prone to typing errors.

Method 1: Create a custom Admin URL from the Magento Admin

Step 1: Login to the Magento 2 backend

To change the Magento 2 admin URL, first, log in to the backend of your Magento 2 store. You can access the backend by adding “/admin” to your Magento 2 website URL.

Step 2: Go to the Configuration section

Once logged in, navigate to the “Stores” menu and click on “Configuration.”

Step 3: Change the Admin URL

Under the “Advanced” section, click on “Admin” and then select “Security.” You will see the “Admin Base URL” section, where you can change the default URL to a custom URL.

Step 4: Save the Changes

After making the changes, don’t forget to save the configuration. To save the changes, click on the “Save Config” button at the top right corner of the page.

Step 5: Clear Cache

Finally, clear the cache to reflect the changes. Go to the “System” menu and select “Cache Management.” Click on the “Flush Magento Cache” button and you’re done.

Conclusion

Great job! You have successfully followed the steps to change the admin URL in Magento 2 and added an extra layer of security to your online store. Having a custom URL makes it harder for hackers to guess and access the backend, which is crucial for the safety of your website.

However, in case you forget your admin URL or get locked out for any reason, there’s no need to worry. You can easily unlock admin user in Magento 2 by following the guidelines provided in the Magento 2 user guide. Alternatively, you can also contact your hosting provider for assistance.

Method 2: Change the Admin Path from Command Line

In addition to changing the Magento 2 admin URL through the backend, you can also change it through the command line. Here are the steps to change the Magento 2 admin URL from the command line:

Step 1: Connect to your server

Use an SSH client such as PuTTY to connect to your server.

Step 2: Navigate to the Magento 2 root directory

Change to the root directory of your Magento 2 installation.

Step 3: Run the following command

python

php bin/magento setup:config:set --backend-frontname=new_admin_url

Replace "new_admin_url" with your desired custom URL.

Step 4: Clear cache:

Clear the Magento 2 cache using the following command:

python

php bin/magento cache:clean

5: Verify the changes

Verify the changes by logging into the backend using the new URL.

Conclusion 

Congratulations! You have successfully changed the Magento 2 admin URL using the command line. This efficient process allows you to modify the URL without accessing the backend, saving you time and effort.

Please note that changing the admin URL requires caution, and it is essential to have a backup of your website before making any adjustments.

nodes.title: How to Manage Shop by Brand in Magento 2
nodes.excerpt: Online store owners widely use Magento 2 as an e-commerce platform to efficiently manage their businesses. It offers a range of features and functionalities that enhance the online shopping experience for customers. Among its features is the “Shop by Brand” option, which helps online stores categorize their products by brand. This blog post provides a … Read more
nodes.content:
Online store owners widely use Magento 2 as an e-commerce platform to efficiently manage their businesses. It offers a range of features and functionalities that enhance the online shopping experience for customers. Among its features is the “Shop by Brand” option, which helps online stores categorize their products by brand.

This blog post provides a detailed guide on how to manage the “Shop by Brand” feature in Magento 2. It covers various aspects such as creating brand categories, assigning products to specific brands, and customizing brand pages’ display. This comprehensive guide aims on How to Manage Shop by Brand in Magento 2, thereby enhancing their customers’ shopping experience.

Steps to Manage Shop by Brand in Magneto 2

Step 1: Install the Brand Extension

To manage your store by brand in Magento 2, you will first need to install a brand extension. There are several extensions available in the Magento Marketplace, including Amasty’s Shop by Brand and Aheadworks’ Shop by Brand.

Step 2: Create a Brand Attribute

Once you have installed the brand extension, you will need to create a brand attribute. This attribute will be used to categorize your products by brand. To create a brand attribute, navigate to Stores > Attributes > Product and click on the Add New Attribute button. Fill in the necessary information, such as the attribute code and label, and select the Catalog Input Type for Store Owner as Dropdown.

Step 3: Assign Brands to Products

After you have created the brand attribute, you will need to assign brands to your products. To do this, navigate to Catalog > Products and select the product you wish to assign a brand to. From there, scroll down to the Brand Attribute section and select the brand from the dropdown menu. Repeat this step for each product you wish to assign a brand to.

Step 4: Create a Brand Page

Now that you have assigned brands to your products, you will need to create a brand page. This page will display all of the products that belong to a specific brand. To create a brand page, navigate to Content > Pages and click on the Add New Page button. Fill in the necessary information, such as the page title and URL key, and select the brand template from the Layout Update XML section.

Step 5: Add the Brand Navigation Block

Finally, you will need to add the brand navigation block to your store’s menu. This will allow customers to easily navigate to the brand page they are interested in. To add the brand navigation block, navigate to Content > Blocks and click on the Add New Block button. Fill in the necessary information, such as the block title and identifier, and add the following code to the Content section:

php

<ul>

  <li><a href="{{store url='brand/nike'}}">Nike</a></li>

  <li><a href="{{store url='brand/adidas'}}">Adidas</a></li>

  <li><a href="{{store url='brand/puma'}}">Puma</a></li>

</ul>

Replace nike, adidas, and puma with the brands you have assigned to your products.

Conclusion

To sum up, utilizing the “Shop by Brand” feature in Magento 2 can prove to be a valuable tool for product organization and enhancing the customer experience. Creating separate pages for each brand enables customers to conveniently browse and compare products from their preferred brands. With the use of attributes and categories, products can be filtered and organized, simplifying the search process for customers. By following the steps provided in this article, you can proficiently manage your shop by brand in Magento 2, resulting in a more streamlined and customer-friendly online store.

nodes.content:
An effectively designed notification bar can be an essential tool to catch your customers’ attention and drive conversions on your Magento 2 store. Whether your objective is to promote a sale, launch a new product, or highlight essential information, a notification bar can help you achieve your targets.

In this comprehensive guide, we will offer you a step-by-step approach for how to add and set up a notification bar in Magento 2. With just a few straightforward steps, you can create an attractive and impactful bar. Whether you are an experienced Magento 2 user or a novice, our guide will help you develop a notification bar that suits your requirements. Get started now and improve your website’s engagement and sales!

What are Notification bars

A notification bar is a graphical user interface element that displays notifications to the user in a small strip on the device screen, typically displayed at the top or bottom of the screen. It provides updates and information to the user about various events and alerts, such as incoming messages, missed calls, battery status, and other system-related notifications. The user can interact with the notification bar to access and manage the notifications.

Steps to Add and Setup Notification Bar in Magento 2 

Step 1: Install a Notification Bar Extension

There are several free and paid Magento 2 extensions available for adding a notification bar to your store. You can choose any extension of your choice and install an extension from Magento 2 Marketplace.

To install the extension, log in to your Magento 2 backend and go to System > Web Setup Wizard > Extension Manager. Search for a suitable extension and click “Install” to start the installation process. Follow the on-screen instructions to complete the installation.

Step 2: Configure the Notification Bar

After installing the extension, log in to your Magento 2 backend and navigate to the extension’s configuration area. From here, you can configure the basic settings for your notification bar, such as its position, background color, and text color.

In the “General Configuration” section, select “Header” for the “Position” field to display the bar at the top of your page. You can also set the background color and text color for the bar.

Step 3: Create a New Notification

To create a new notification, click the “Add New Notification” button. Fill in the necessary information, such as the notification title, message, and display conditions. You can also choose from several different styles and animation effects to make your notification stand out.

In the “Title” field, enter the text you want to display in the bar. In the “Content” field, enter the message you want to display. You can use HTML to format the message and add links.

Step 4: Set up the conditions, design, and display of the new promo bar

Conditions:

Display:

Step 4: Enable the Notification Bar

Make sure to enable your notification bar by selecting the “Enabled” option. You can also set the bar to display at specific times by using the “From” and “To” fields.

In the “Status” field, select “Enabled” to enable the bar. If you want to set the bar to display only at specific times, select the “From” and “To” fields and enter the start and end times for the bar.

Step 5: Preview the Notification Bar

Preview your notification bar by visiting your store’s frontend. You should see the bar displayed at the top of the page, with your message and a close button.

Step 6: Customize the Notification Bar

You can further customize your notification bar by adjusting its position, adding a link, or including a call-to-action button. To make these changes, simply go back to the backend and edit your bar’s settings.

In the “Position” field, you can change the position of the bar to display at the top or bottom of the page. In the “Content” field, you can add a link or call-to-action button to the message.

Conclusion

To sum up, incorporating a notification bar into your Magento 2 store is an uncomplicated process that can significantly boost its success. By utilizing this feature, you can enhance customer engagement, boost sales, and increase conversions. It’s vital to test different styles and messages to discover what resonates best with your store to achieve optimal outcomes. Don’t hesitate to experiment and try novel approaches. With the convenience of adding and configuring a notification bar in Magento 2, there’s no justification for not leveraging this effective tool to advance the prosperity of your online enterprise.

nodes.title: How to Fix 500 Internal Server Error in Magento 2
nodes.excerpt: Magento 2 is a popular e-commerce platform that offers robust features and functionalities for online stores. Nevertheless, it is not impervious to technical glitches, and one of the most prevalent problems that store owners encounter is the 500 Internal Server Error. This error message typically appears when there is an issue with the server or … Read more
nodes.content:
Magento 2 is a popular e-commerce platform that offers robust features and functionalities for online stores. Nevertheless, it is not impervious to technical glitches, and one of the most prevalent problems that store owners encounter is the 500 Internal Server Error.

This error message typically appears when there is an issue with the server or website configuration and can be incredibly vexing for store owners, as it impedes access to the site. In this blog post, we will explore different techniques to help you learn how to fix 500 internal server error in Magento 2. 

Whether you are a technical expert or a novice, this guide will provide you with a step-by-step approach to addressing this problem and restoring the smooth operation of your online store. Whether you prefer to troubleshoot this issue on your own or enlist the help of a professional, this guide will furnish you with all the necessary information to bring your online store back online swiftly.

What does 500 Internal Server Error in Magento 2 mean

The 500 Internal Server Error in Magento 2 is a specific indication that there is an issue with the process of how to install Magento 2 on server-side. This error can stem from a variety of causes, including improper server configurations, glitches with Magento 2 modules, insufficient memory or processing power, or problems with the website or application code. When this error occurs, it hinders user access to the site and can lead to a loss of business for the website owner.

To resolve the 500 Internal Server Error in Magento 2, it is essential to identify and rectify the root cause of the issue, which may involve troubleshooting server configurations, deactivating or updating modules, boosting memory and processing power, or repairing code. In general, if you are unable to resolve the 500 Internal Server Error in Magento 2 on your own, it is advisable to enlist the help of a professional.

Methods to Fix 500 Internal Server Error in Magento 2

Fix the File Permissions:

The directory structure of Magento 2 has predefined file and folder permissions. However, when you install an extension or update Magento 2 on the server, it can alter those permissions. This can lead to the appearance of the Magento 500 internal server error when trying to log in to the admin panel.

One way to address this is by adjusting the file permissions of the index.php file in the root directory, changing it from 664 to 644 using your website’s file manager. By resetting permissions, you may be able to resolve the Magento 500 error.

Please run the following commands to set the permissions:

find . -type f -exec chmod 644 {} \;

find . -type d -exec chmod 755 {} \;

find ./var -type d -exec chmod 777 {} \;

find ./pub/media -type d -exec chmod 777 {} \;

find ./pub/static -type d -exec chmod 777 {} \;

chmod 777 ./app/etc

chmod 644 ./app/etc/*.xml

chmod u+x bin/Magento

Check Server Logs: 


The initial step to fixing the 500 Internal Server Error is to examine the server logs. These logs can offer important clues about what might have caused the error. You can locate the logs either in the control panel of the server or in the installation folder of Magento 2. 

Disable Magento 2 Modules: 

Another potential cause of the 500 Internal Server Error in the Magento 2 module. To pinpoint the culprit, you can try disabling the modules one by one. Access the Magento 2 backend, go to the “Stores” section, and click on “Configuration.” Then, select the “Advanced” tab and click on “Advanced.” Locate the module you suspect is causing the error, and set its status to “Disabled.”

Check PHP Version: 

Having the correct PHP version is essential for Magento 2 to operate without any errors. If the PHP version on your server is outdated, this can result in a 500 Internal Server Error. You can easily verify the PHP version by accessing the control panel of your server and selecting “PHP Information.”

Fix Issues with the .htaccess File

To resolve a 500 Internal Server Error that’s caused by incorrect configuration in the .htaccess file, you can try renaming or removing the .htaccess file and then reloading the website to see if the error disappears.

If the Magento 500 internal server error disappears, it means that there was a configuration problem with the .htaccess file that needs to be addressed. However, be mindful of any potential issues with broken 404 links in your store that may arise as a result of this fix.

Increase PHP Memory Limit: 

Insufficient memory on the server can cause a 500 Internal Server Error in Magento 2. Therefore, it is necessary to ensure that your server has sufficient memory to run Magento 2. You can increase the PHP memory limit by editing the .htaccess file in the Magento 2 installation folder. You need to add this code line to the .htaccess file: “php_value memory_limit 512M.”

Re-upload Core Files: 

If the previous troubleshooting steps fail to resolve the issue, another option to try is to re-upload the core files of Magento 2. This can help replace any damaged or corrupted files and potentially fix the 500 Internal Server Error.

Conclusion

In summary, there are multiple techniques available to resolve the 500 Internal Server Error in Magento 2. However, if you find yourself unable to resolve the issue, it’s best to seek the assistance of a professional. Rest assured that with the appropriate solution, your online store can be back up and running smoothly in no time.

Adobe’s platform-based online solution offers rule-based tax calculation automation through the Magento system. It applies … Read more
nodes.content:
How Taxes Work in Magento 2 Store and What Tax Configurations are Available: Taxes have always been a complex issue, and businesses seek to automate their calculations to make it easier for managers and improve the shopping experience for customers. Adobe’s platform-based online solution offers rule-based tax calculation automation through the Magento system. It applies charging rules based on customer information, item classes, customer shipping and billing addresses, and store location.

In Magento 2, a manager can set up multiple item classes to separate taxes, based on the item information, customer information, charge zones, and rates. The store’s admin interface provides the following tax sections for easy configuration and management.

Key Tax Configurations You Should Consider

With various tax configurations available, it can be challenging to determine the best settings for your store. This overview will provide you with the necessary information on how taxes work in Magento 2 store and what tax configurations are available.

General Tax Settings:

Tax Configuration for eCommerce Businesses: This page provides a guide for essential tax settings for eCommerce businesses on how taxes work in Magento 2 store and what tax configurations are available. Before setting up these elements, a manager should be aware of the tax requirements in the shop’s specific area. Then, they can proceed with the configuration accordingly. Understanding the available tax configurations and settings in Magento 2 is crucial to ensure that your eCommerce store complies with relevant tax laws and requirements. With various tax-related configurations available, it can be challenging to determine the best settings for your store. However, by following this guide, you can set up the correct tax configurations to avoid overcharging or undercharging taxes, which can lead to legal complications and financial losses.

Tax Rules: 

The tax rules comprise a combination of client and item classes and respective expense rates. Each client is assigned to a tax class, and each item is allocated to a tax class. The system analyzes each client’s order and calculates the appropriate tax based on the client and item classes, as well as the area determined by the client’s shipping, billing, or delivery address.

Tax Classes: 

Tax classes can be assigned to clients, items, and shipping services. The system examines each customer’s order and calculates the tax based on the customer’s class, the ordered items, and the customer’s district, which is determined by their shipping, billing, or delivery address. New tax classes can be created when introducing tax rules.

Fixed Product Tax: 

Some local districts have a mandatory fee that should be added to specific items. Based on the store’s tax calculations, a manager can set up this charge as a fixed value (FPT). For example, in some countries, FPT may be used to set up a WEEE tax, also known as an environmental tax or eco-tax. This type of fee is collected on certain electronics to offset the cost of recycling old electronic devices and is a predefined amount rather than a percentage of the item cost.

The Price Display Setting:

determines whether the displayed price for an item and its shipping costs include the tax amount. It’s possible to show two versions of the price, one with and one without tax.

Tax Zones and Rates:

set the tax rate for each geographic region where taxation is collected. The manager can indicate the rate for each region and assign an identifier, allowing different rates for the same region if necessary, such as regions that exempt certain items like food or medication.

Value Added Tax (VAT):

is a tax charged on goods and services in some countries, with rates that vary based on the stage of production or distribution. In some cases, multiple VAT rates may be used for tax calculation purposes.

The Tax Quick Reference

provides options for determining how taxes are calculated and presented to the customer. The Hidden Tax conditions determine the amount of VAT that a discount has, and is non-zero when catalog prices include tax, the VAT rate is not zero, and a discount is present.

International Tax Guidelines 

apply to the income earned from overseas operations and sales, with tax treaties between countries determining which country collects the tax revenue, and anti-avoidance rules limiting opportunities to minimize the global tax burden.

Vertex Cloud:

is a cloud-based solution that automates sales tax compliance and generates a signature-ready PDF for monthly returns. A Vertex account is required, with configuration options available for tax settings, address cleansing for the store, country overrides, and performance-enhancing options.

Summary

Magento 2 provides store owners with great flexibility in managing taxes. However, it requires careful attention and significant interaction, particularly in eCommerce. How tax is calculated in Magento 2 and how to set up tax rules in Magento 2 are important aspects that store owners or managers must understand. Since tax systems vary from country to country, it is crucial to research and fully comprehend the tax expense requirements in the countries where the store operates before setting up tax rules, rates, or classes in Magento 2.

There are many high-quality Magento 2 extensions available that provide full control and configuration of taxes, making it an advantage for any eCommerce business. Using a custom price template in Magento 2 can also help streamline the process of managing taxes and make it more efficient for store owners.

nodes.title: How to setup Magento 2 login with social account
nodes.excerpt: Social login has emerged as a favored feature among e-commerce stores, owing to its ability to enable customers to log in to their site effortlessly and speedily using their existing social media account. By integrating Magento 2 social login, you can simplify the login process for your customers and enhance the overall user experience of … Read more
nodes.content:
Social login has emerged as a favored feature among e-commerce stores, owing to its ability to enable customers to log in to their site effortlessly and speedily using their existing social media account. By integrating Magento 2 social login, you can simplify the login process for your customers and enhance the overall user experience of your store.

This blog post will furnish you with a step-by-step tutorial on how to setup Magento 2 login with a social account. It will cover everything from selecting the right extension to personalizing the social login buttons, providing you with all the crucial information you require to get started with Magento 2 social login. Regardless of whether you are a novice or seasoned Magento 2 user, this guide will equip you with all the necessary details.

Why you need a Magento 2 social login extension

There are several advantages to using a Magento 2 social login extension, including:

1. Convenience: With social login, customers can access your store using their existing social media account, eliminating the need to create a new account specifically for your store.

2. Increased Conversion Rates: Social login simplifies the login process, reducing the likelihood of abandoned shopping carts and improving conversion rates.

3. Improved User Experience: Social login offers a personalized experience for customers, enhancing the likelihood of repeat business.

4. Increased Security: Many social media platforms employ advanced security measures, offering a secure and trustworthy login option for your customers.

5. Enhanced Customer Insights: Social login enables you to gather valuable customer data and insights, such as demographic information and social media activity, which can be used to improve your marketing and customer engagement strategies.

In summary, a Magento 2 social login extension can offer several benefits for your online store, improving the customer experience and increasing conversion rates.

Steps to Setup Magento 2 Login with Social Account

Step 1: Install the Social Login Extension

First, you need to install a social login extension for Magento 2. You can also install extension in magento 2 manually.There are many free and paid options available on the market, including Magento Marketplace. Choose one that fits your needs and install it through the Magento 2 backend. 

Step 2: Set Up the Social Login Extension

Once the extension is installed, you need to set it up. This usually involves creating a developer account on the social media platform, generating API keys and entering them into the extension’s settings.

Step 3: Enable the Social Login Buttons

Next, you need to enable the social login buttons on your Magento 2 store. This can usually be done from the extension’s settings in the Magento 2 backend.

Step 4: Customize the Social Login Buttons

You can also customize the appearance of the social login buttons to match your store’s design. This can be done through the extension’s settings in the Magento 2 backend.

Step 5: Test the Social Login Functionality

Once the social login buttons are enabled, you can test the functionality to make sure it works correctly. Try logging in through a few different social media platforms to make sure everything is working as expected.

Step 6: Make Social Login the Default Login Method

Finally, you can make social login the default login method for your Magento 2 store. This will ensure that your customers are presented with the social login options first, making it easier and more convenient for them to log in.Now select Yes to enable the AJAX pop-up for the process of registration and login.

You can also set the login button’s position, choose the place or position you want to display the social login buttons. Now redirect after login and select from the box the page that you want your customers to direct to after their social login.

Conclusion

To sum up, integrating social login into Magento 2 is an uncomplicated and direct process, much like how to set up Magento 2 itself, that can significantly enhance the customer experience in your store. With the appropriate extension and a few customization tweaks, you can have a complete social login configuration up and running in a jiffy.

nodes.content:
How to setup Google Tag Manager in Magento 2 store – Tracking visitor behavior on your online store is crucial for boosting profits. By identifying pages where customers abandon their carts, you can eliminate the issue and increase sales. Google Tag Manager (GTM) is a popular service used to gather customer journey data through small event tracking. GTM is managed through a web interface and must be configured to track visitor steps. This configuration requires setting up your store, GTM service, and analytics service (such as Google Analytics 4). A guide to setting up GTM in Magento 2 store is available for reference.

How to Setup Google Tag Manager in Magento 2 Store: A Step-by-Step Guide

What is Google Tag Manager

Google Tag Manager (GTM) is a powerful tool that can be used to track website activity, including eCommerce transactions, and can be integrated with Magento 2 using a Magento 2 Google Tag Manager module. Tracking website activity typically requires a specific code for each event to be tracked, which can make tracking a complex and time-consuming process involving significant website changes. However, GTM simplifies this process by allowing you to manage tracking tags through a user-friendly web interface, without the need for extensive website modifications.

To set up Google Tag Manager in your Magento 2 store, you can use the Magento 2 Google Tag Manager module. How to setup Google Tag Manager in Magento 2 store is a straightforward process that only requires adding two GTM code snippets. With this integration, businesses can gain valuable insights into user behavior, allowing them to optimize their marketing strategies, increase conversion rates, and ultimately, boost revenue.

By using the Magento 2 Google Tag Manager module, you can seamlessly integrate GTM with your store without having to modify your store’s theme templates. This makes the integration process even simpler and more efficient. If you’re looking to take your eCommerce efforts to the next level, integrating Magento 2 with GTM is a crucial step that can provide significant benefits for your business.

Why a GTM extension for Magento is recommended

To learn how to setup Google Tag Manager in Magento 2 store, you must add GTM code snippets to your store’s frontend theme. Adobe Commerce edition of Magento offers a built-in interface for adding GTM code. However, Magento Open Source stores need to use a third-party extension, such as the “Google Tag Manager & Facebook Pixel for Magento 2,” which supports the Hyva theme and comes with preconfigured GTM tags, as well as support for the Facebook Pixel tracker. A guide to installing the extension is available, which can help you integrate GTM with your Magento 2 store and start gaining valuable insights into user behavior.

Note: The built-in Google Tag Manager module will be available in Magento 2.4.5, starting from August 9, 2022.

Instructions for Setting Up GTM in Magento 2

This guide covers the GTM setup for the Magento Open Source edition. The “Google Tag Manager & Facebook Pixel for Magento 2” extension is used to connect to the Google Tag Manager service. To use the GTM Magento extension, you need to provide three identifiers: GTM Account ID, GTM Container ID, and either Google Analytics 4 Measurement ID or Google Analytics 3 Tracking ID.

Step 1: Establish a GTM Account and Container.

  • Go to the Google Tag Manager website and log in with your Gmail credentials. 
  • Click the “Create Account” button, 
  • provide a name for the account in the “Account Setup” section, and select your country.
  • Set up the account container by specifying a name and selecting the target platform. Choose “Web” if you are collecting data from a website. 

Note: To delete a container, go to Admin -> Container Settings -> More (three vertical dots) -> Settings -> Delete. Google provides a 30-day window for restoration. After that, the container will be permanently deleted.

Step 2: Retrieve your GTM Account ID and Container ID.

To retrieve the GTM Container ID, go to the GTM homepage, click on the container name, and find the Container ID in the browser address bar after “containerId=”.

Make note of the Container ID, as you will need to enter it into your Magento store. 

Note: The required Container ID is a 10-digit number, not the formatted “GTM-N48BDMV” version shown in the GTM interface.

To retrieve the GTM Account ID, 

open your container and look at the URL of the current page in the browser address bar. The GTM Account ID can be found after “accounts” in the URL and should be noted as you will need to enter it into your Magento store.

Step 3: Retrieve Google Analytics 4 Measurement ID

To obtain the Google Analytics 4 Measurement ID, log in to your Google Analytics account and navigate to the tracking code setup. The Measurement ID can be found in the code provided and should be written down for later use in the GTM setup process.

  • Access GA4 property for Magento tracking
  • In the Properties & Apps section, select the Google Analytics 4 property used for tracking events in your Magento store.

To find your Google Analytics 4 Measurement ID:

If your GA4 property has received no data, go to the Properties&Apps block and select the GA4 property you use to track events in your Magento store. The Measurement ID will be immediately visible.

If your GA4 property is already receiving data, go to Admin > Property column > Data Streams > Web data stream. Write down the Measurement ID, as you will need to paste it into your Magento store.

Step 4: Obtain the GTM Installation Code Snippet

Go to the GTM home page and select the container you want to use.

On the container page, click on the container ID to open the “Install Google Tag Manager” window.

Copy the code snippets for the <head> and <body> tags provided in the window.

Step 5. Add GTM Code and IDs to Magento Store

Go to Stores > Configuration > Mirasvit Extensions > Google Tag Manager and set Enable GTM to Yes. Then, paste the <head> code snippet in the GTM Regular Code field and the <body> code snippet in the GTM No-Script Code field.

In the Container Import section, paste the previously obtained GTM Account ID, GTM Container ID, and Analytics Measurement ID into their respective fields.

Step 6. Create GTM Tags

To track events, you need to create separate tags and triggers within the GTM service. Start by importing the container information from the GTM Magento extension into your GTM account. In Magento, click the Download Import File for Google Analytics 4 button and save the JSON file.

In GTM, go to the homepage, and click the gear icon. Select the Import container, choose the JSON import file, workspace (usually the Default Workspace), and the import method (overwrite or merge). Preview and confirm the import to see the number of new GTM tags, tag triggers, and tag variables added to the container.

Creating a New GTM Tag:

In the GTM container, navigate to the Workspace and click the New Tag card. Provide a descriptive name for the tag, such as “Tag Type – App Name – Detail.” Then, click Tag Configuration.

Select the GTM tag type, such as GA4 Event. Set the Configuration Tag, for example, GA4 – Configuration, and choose the Event Name from the list. Save the tag and add a trigger when prompted.

If you imported a set of triggers from the GTM Magento extension, you will have a list of available triggers. Otherwise, you need to create a new trigger by clicking the + sign.

Creating a New GTM Tag Trigger:

Click the + sign, then the Trigger Configuration. Choose the Trigger Type, such as 

Page View : 

  • Consent Initialization,
  • Initialization,
  • DOM Ready, 
  • Window Loaded 

Click :

  • Element Visibility,
  • Form Submission, 
  • Scroll Depth, 
  • YouTube Video, 

Other :

  • Custom Event.
  • History Change
  • JavaScript Error
  • Timer
  • Trigger Group

Next, choose where the trigger will activate. Each trigger type has different activation options. For instance, a Page View trigger can be set to activate on all page views or only on certain page views.

Step 7. Activate GTM tags

Activate the tags by clicking the Submit button and selecting Submission Configuration as Publish and Create Version. Enter a Version Name and, if desired, a Version Description, then click Publish.

Click on the three vertical dots (More) and choose to Publish version to receive a message that the published version is live.

Step 8. Check GTM tag functionality

After creating the tags, it is important to verify that they are working correctly to avoid any configuration mistakes.

Locate the latest live version of the tag, click on the three vertical dots (More), and select Preview.

You will be redirected to the Tag Assistant web page. Enter the URL of your store and click Connect.

Your store will open in a new browser window, and if the GTM service is successfully connected to your store, you will see the Tag Assistant Connected window.

Click Continue in the Tag Assistant.

You will then see a page that monitors the performance of your tags. On your store, perform actions that should fire the tag you want to test.

For example, to test the view_item tag, navigate to a product page on your store. The Tag Assistant should show that the tag has been executed.

Verify that your Google Analytics 4 is receiving the tracking data by navigating to the Realtime report and observing the activity on the site in the last five minutes.”

Summary

In conclusion, Google Tag Manager is a powerful tool for tracking user activity in your Magento 2 store. While it can be challenging to set up and manage tags, there are several resources available to help streamline the process. By following our step-by-step guide on how to add Google Tag Manager to Magento 2, you can easily launch user activity tracking through GTM. With the help of Magento 2 Advanced Reports, you can take your analytics and report to the next level, gaining valuable insights into your e-commerce store’s performance. By leveraging these tools, you can improve your marketing strategies and increase your store’s revenue. And, if you’re looking to add Google Analytics code to your Magento 2 store, follow the How to add Google Analytics code to Magento 2 guide for a smooth setup process.

nodes.content:
Running a sustainable online store is not easy. The manager must dedicate time to tasks like monitoring inventory levels, arranging shipments, balancing supply and demand, etc. These tasks can sometimes lead to items being out of stock, which is a common challenge for web-based stores of all sizes. If you’re using Magento 2, you can enable low-stock email notifications to stay on top of inventory levels and avoid stockouts. In this tutorial, we’ll show you how to enable low stock email notification in Magento 2.

To address the common challenge of out-of-stock items, Magento 2 admin can set up sending low stock notifications to ensure timely replenishment of inventory. This feature, also known as Magento 2 low stock notification, allows the admin to receive alerts when the stock of a particular item reaches a specified minimum level. Out-of-stock items can negatively impact customers, causing dissatisfaction and increased shopping cart abandonment. To mitigate this, offering back-in-stock notifications can convert potential customers into actual sales and bring them back to the store. Additionally, to make order status visible on the front end in Magento 2, the How to Make Order Status Visible on Frontend in Magento 2 article provides guidance on this process. The How to set up sending a low stock notification for Magento 2 admin article also offers information on how to effectively manage your store’s inventory.

How to Set Up Sending a Low Stock Notification for Magento 2 Admin: A Step-by-Step Guide

Manage low-quantity notifications in the default configuration

A warning message may be received by a manager when the available stock of a product drops to a critical level. Magento 2 admin allows the trader to set up these alerts in several areas of the admin panel:

1. Notify for Quantity Below field in the Stores configuration menu under Settings > Configuration > Catalog > Inventory > Product Stock Options sets a default threshold for all items on the site.

2. Advanced Inventory Notify for Quantity Below field (found under Catalog > Products > specific product > Advanced Inventory) overrides the website/store level setting and applies to all sources of the product.

3. Notify Quantity fields (located in Catalog > Products > specific product > Assigned Sources section) are the highest priority setting. The merchant can set a unique threshold for each source of a specific product.

Magento’s Stock Management: Deduction of Global or Overriding Quantity

Magento subtracts either the global or the overriding quantity from the total available stock to determine the salable quantity.

The REST low-quantity notification endpoints allow merchants to manage their values set in the Notify Quantity fields.

How to get a daily Summary of low Stock by email.

Create Custom Low Stock Report with Advanced Reports Magento 2

With Advanced Reports Magento 2, you can create a custom report specifically for tracking low stock levels. Check out the demo store for an example of this type of report.

Once created, you can schedule automatic report submissions to be sent directly to your email. This provides you with regular, accurate updates on your store’s inventory balances.

Planning your inventory supply

Maximize Profits with Inventory Planning in Magento: Use the Inventory Planner Module

Proper inventory supply planning is crucial for maximizing profits and efficiently utilizing warehouse space. However, inventory planning in Magento is not a built-in feature and requires the use of spreadsheets or external platforms, which can be time-consuming to set up and manage. To address this challenge, Magento 2 admin can set up sending a low stock notification to receive alerts when inventory levels reach a specified minimum threshold. In addition to this feature, the Inventory Planner module can also be used to automate the inventory forecasting process. With this extension, you will know exactly when and in what quantities to replenish your products, as well as identify any surplus items. In this tutorial, we’ll show you how to set up sending a low stock notification for Magento 2 admin and how to use the Inventory Planner module to optimize your inventory management.

The module eliminates the need for manual calculation and arrangement and is smart enough to make forecasts on its own. Benefits of using the Inventory Planner module include:

1. Optimization of stock planning procedures.

2. Increased confidence in scheduling inventory replenishments.

3. Easy identification of overstocked items.

4.No setup is required after installation.

5. Working speed is not impacted by the size of the product catalog.

Conclusion

In conclusion, proper inventory supply planning is essential for maximizing profits and utilizing warehouse space efficiently. With the Inventory Planner module for Magento, store managers can easily and accurately forecast their inventory needs, saving time and effort in manual calculations and arrangements. With its advanced features, the module helps optimize stock planning procedures, increase confidence in inventory replenishments, and identify overstocked items. In addition to these benefits, Magento 2 admin can also set up sending a low stock notification to receive alerts when inventory levels reach a specified minimum threshold. Whether you have a large or small product catalog, the Inventory Planner module provides a smart and efficient solution for your inventory planning needs. nodes.excerpt: How the checkout process is organized in Magento 2: The most common way to complete a purchase in an online store is through the online checkout process. When a customer adds an item to their digital shopping cart, they usually complete the purchase. To finalize the transaction in a Magento 2 eCommerce website, the customer … Read more
nodes.content:
How the checkout process is organized in Magento 2: The most common way to complete a purchase in an online store is through the online checkout process. When a customer adds an item to their digital shopping cart, they usually complete the purchase.

To finalize the transaction in a Magento 2 eCommerce website, the customer must enter mandatory details such as delivery and payment options and sending payment. The checkout process steps depend on whether the customer uses an existing account or chooses the guest checkout option.

Regardless of the method chosen, the purchasing process should provide an improved experience for the customer. For example, some customers may prefer a specific payment option, while others may be in a hurry and not have time to create an account. In the latter case, guest checkout can be helpful.

These are the steps in the customer’s purchase journey through the checkout process in Magento 2, as part of the process of creating an eCommerce website using Magento 2.

The checkout process in eCommerce

The checkout process begins when the shopper clicks the “Add to Cart” button and ends when payment is completed or the confirmation page is displayed. The process should be designed to provide a smooth and enjoyable experience for the shopper to maintain their interest in the purchase.

A merchant has two objectives during the checkout process:

1. Collect the customer’s information, such as their name, email, shipping address, telephone number, etc., to use for personalized advertising, special promotions, or to facilitate future orders.

2. Complete the payment process for the customer’s item and gather the payment information.

The exact number of steps in the checkout process may vary, but the two main objectives remain consistent. The success of these objectives, without causing frustration for the customer, depends on the efficiency of the checkout flow design.

In General, the majority of checkout actions include:

1. Adding items to the cart: Potential buyers add the desired item to their cart. This shows that they are serious about making a purchase.

2. Billing: At this stage, the seller creates a consolidated invoice with relevant information such as the customer’s name, cost, and quantity of items. The invoice also includes shipping charges and the final total.

3. Shipping: The customer enters information such as delivery address and transportation method, and selects a payment option, such as online banking, digital wallets, or physical money transfer. The available options depend on the store policy and the customer’s location.

4. Confirmation: This is the final stage where the customer agrees to the payment. This step is important as it prevents any confusion or changes in the customer’s mindset. Although the customer may be willing to pay, the store should not take payment without the customer’s explicit confirmation.

Once an order is placed, the buyer has the option to create an account on the website. A verified account offers the following benefits to the buyer:

1. Access to their purchase history

2. The ability to save shipping and billing information for future orders

3. Eligibility for promotions and discounts.

For the seller, having a customer account allows them to:

1. Personalize offers based on previous purchases

2. Send company emails, solicit feedback, and keep the customer informed

3. Implement bonus campaigns, offer coupons and discounts

4. Start affiliate programs to increase conversions.

It’s worth noting that Magento 2 offers various extensions that can enhance the registration process and related features.

Conclusion

In conclusion, the question How does Magento 2 checkout work? and How the checkout process is organized in Magento 2 are important considerations for e-commerce store owners. To ensure a positive customer experience, it’s essential to keep the checkout process easy and convenient. Customers should be able to place an order in 1-2 steps without having to register. By streamlining and optimizing the checkout flow, you can reduce abandoned shopping carts and increase conversion rates, ultimately leading to increased profits for your business.

Magento 2’s built-in checkout process can be customized to suit your store’s needs, and extensions like One Step Checkout can further simplify the process and improve the customer experience. By prioritizing a seamless checkout process and understanding how the checkout process is organized in Magento 2, you can enhance your customers’ satisfaction and boost your store’s success.
